subordinate noun [C]
(PERSON)
a person who has a less important position than you in an organization: He left the routine checks to one of his subordinates.

subordinate noun [C]
(WORD)
language
  specialized a word whose meaning is included in the meaning of another word: "Dog" is a subordinate of the category "pet". Compare
superordinate
to put someone or something into a less important position: Her personal life has been subordinated to her career.

having a lower or less important position: I’m happy in a subordinate role. subordinate noun [ C ] us
Your browser doesn't support HTML5 audio
/səˈbɔr·dən·ət/
You need to assign this job to a subordinate.
to treat someone or something as less important than something else: Japan has a tradition of subordinating individual desires to group goals. subordination noun [ U ] us/səˌbɔr·dənˈeɪ·ʃən/
She studies patterns of domination and subordination among orangutans.
Add to word list
Add to word list
WORKPLACE having less power or a lower position than someone else in a company or an organization: subordinate to sb The condition of motherhood often makes women subordinate to men in the workplace.a subordinate employee/position/role Before reaching the level of head chef, there was the hard work and subordinate positions in kitchens. Women are in the minority in the office and are of subordinate status to most of their male colleagues.
less important than something else: Primary legislation can be amended; subordinate legislation cannot.subordinate to sth The institute will make the acquired debt subordinate to any new bank lending.
[ before noun ]
  FINANCE →
subordinated
WORKPLACE a person who has a less important position than you in a company or an organization: Senior managers had to convince their colleagues and subordinates of the value of this approach.
to put someone or something into a less important position: Management found itself subordinated to the markets.
